s.gd: Faodaidh tu seasamh rè latha air Drochaid na Caoidh ag èisdeachd ri guileig a’ ghuilbnich ’s ri fuaim an uisge a’ cagair gu binn anns na linneachan: no faodaidh tu amharc air aodann nam mòr-bheann a tha ag èirigh air gach taobh den ghleann uaigneach anns an eilean air nach bi ainm.
s.en: You may stand during a day on the Bridge of Mourning listening to the warbling of the curlews and to the sound of the water whispering sweetly in the pools: or you may behold the face of the great mountains that are rising on each side of the remote nameless glen on the island.

s.gd: Ach air ciaradh don fheasgar cha ghabh thu an rathad seo.
s.en: But at evening twilight you will not take this road.

s.gd: Tha cagailtean càirdeil far an dèan iad do bheatha agus far am faod thu feitheamh ri èirigh na grèine.
s.en: There are friendly hearths where they will make your life and where you may wait for sunrise.

s.gd: Gheibh thu fàilte ’s furan nan eilean — an spàin-adhairc agus an taobh as blàithe den teine.
s.en: You will get a welcome and island hospitality – the horn spoon and the warmest side of the fire.

s.gd: ’S chan e guileag a’ ghuilbnich no cagar an uillt no osnadh nam beann a chuireas eagal ort, ach gaoir tiamhaidh mnà ’s i caoidh.
s.en: And it is not the curlew’s warbling nor the whispering of the stream not the sighing of the mountains that will frighten you, but plaintive humming of a woman and her mourning.

s.gd: Nach iongnadh leat mar a nì mnathan caoidh airson a’ chealgair, an fhir-fhuadain, an duine gun stèidh, a chionn ’s gu bheil e flathail na phearsa, gaisgeil na ghiùlan, no theagamh deas gu bradan a thoirt à linne no ruaig a chur air an damh chròiceach.
s.en: It will not surprise you how woman will mourn for the deceiver, the vagabond, the unprincipled man, because he is princely in his person, heroic in his conduct, or perhaps able to get a salmon from a pond or chase off the antlered stag.

s.gd: Bha a’ cheart smuain aig Mòrag NicGilleathain ’s i na suidhe aig a gealbhan fhèin, a sùilean air toit na mòna bha ’g èirigh gu na tarsannan.
s.en: Morag MacLean had the right thought as she was sat by her own hearth, her eyes on the peat smoke that was rising to the crossbeams.

s.gd: Trì bliadhna on a thàinig crìoch air a’ chogadh san Fhraing, ach cha do thill Ailean, a cèile — Ailean a thilg uaith an corran airson a’ chlaidheimh — Ailean a’ chridhe aotroim, na coise siùbhlaich, ’s na sùla mireagaich daonnan ri spòrs.
s.en: Three years since the war in France had ended, but Alan had not returned, her spouse – Alan who threw from her the sickle for the sword – Alan of the light heart, the speedy foot, and the mirthful eye always looking for fun.

s.gd: B’e an aon àm nach b’fheàrr air gealladh na air dèanadas e oidhche gheamhraidh nuair thogadh e an fhiodhall bhàrr a’ bhalla ’s a chuireadh e air ghleus i, ’s a chluicheadh e seana phuirt nan eilean, fhad ’s a bhiodh Mòrag a’ snìomh ri taobh an teine.
s.en: The one time ... better ... promise ... performance ... when he would lift the fiddle off the wall and he would put it in tune, and he would play old tunes of the islands, while Morag would be spinning beside the fire.

s.gd: Ach cha do thill Ailean agus ’s ann air Mòraig ’s air Màiri, a nighean, a thuit obair na croite — Mòrag nan sùilean gorma air am biodh aoibh an còmhnaidh, agus Màiri le suaip ri h-athair na sùilean agus a chridhealas na nàdar.
s.en: But Alan had not returned and it was on Morag and Mary, her daughter, that the croft work fell – Morag of the blue eyes which were always affable, and Mary with a faint resemblance to ger father in her eyes and his cheerfulness in her nature.

s.gd: Fad làithean goirid a’ gheamhraidh ghiùlain iad an fheamainn an craileagan don chroit agus san oidhche, ri solas a’ chrùisgein, bha iad ri càrdadh ’s ri snìomh.
s.en: During the short days of the winter they carried the seaweed in wool baskets to the croft and at night, bu the light of the oil-lamp, they were carding and spinning.

s.gd: San earrach thionndaidh iad am fearann leis a’ chois-chruim agus gheàrr iad mòine sa’ bhlàr.
s.en: In the spring they turned the ground with the foot plough and they cut peat in the field.

s.gd: Air feasgar aig deireadh an fhoghair, bha Mòrag na suidhe ri taobh an teine, sgìth le saothair an latha, ’s i beachdachadh air làithean a bha seachad ’s air bliadhnachan a bha ri teachd.
s.en: On an evening at the end of autumn, Morag was dsat beside the fire, tired with the day’s labour, thinking about days that were past and about years that were to come.

s.gd: “A Mhàiri,” ars ise, “chan ann an taigh do mhàthar bu chòir dhut a bhith snìomh, agus Alasdair Caimbeul leis fhèin thall an Grianan.
s.en: “Mary,” she said, “it is not in the house of your mother that you should be spinning, and Alexander Campbell by himself over there in Grianan.

s.gd: ’S math am fearann a th’aige ri cois Allt na Teangaidh, ’s càite eile am faighear sealladh cho brèagha air Stafa no air Lunga no air A’ Bhac Mhòr?”
s.en: It is good the land that he has at the foot of Tongue Burn, and where else will one get such a beautiful view over Staffa or over Lunga or over The Big Block.”

s.gd: “Cho fad ’s a tha sibhse leibh fhèin, cha phòs mise,” fhreagair Màiri.
s.en: “As long as you are by yourself, I will not marry,” Mary replied.
